title: Fluorescence-resonance-energy-transfer-based assay to estimate modulation of TDP1 activity through arginine methylation
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of TDP1 enzyme
Purification of recombinant TDP1 protein (in-vitro)
Timing: 3 days
In this step, Human Tyrosyl DNA Phosphodiesterase (TDP1) is recombinantly expressed in E. coli BL21 DE3 and purified (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Expression of protein
BL21 (DE3) cells is made chemically competent with calcium chloride using Hanahan’s method.24[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib24]
Transform the competent cells with (HisTDP1WT) plasmid16[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16],25[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib25] containing ampicillin resistance gene encoding codon optimized synthetic gene containing TDP1 .
Select the transformed cells by plating them onto agar plate with ampicillin (100 μg/mL) and incubating overnight for 12–18 h at 37°C.
Next day, pick a single colony and add it to a 50 mL Luria Bertani26[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib26] broth prepared in 250 mL Erlenmeyer glass flasks containing 100 μg/mL ampicillin and keep it at 37°C overnight (12–18 h) culture.
Prepare and autoclave 500 mL LB broth for protein purification.
Next morning, use the primary culture (50 mL) to inoculate the secondary culture (500 mL) prepared in 1000 mL Erlenmeyer glass flasks. Add ampicillin to the secondary culture at a concentration of 100 μg/mL and keep it on a shaker incubator at 37°C with 250 rpm shaking.
When the secondary culture reaches absorbance between 0.4-0.6 (late log phase) at 600 nm, induce protein expression with 0.75 mM IPTG (Isopropyl b-D-1-thiogalactopyranoside).
Note: To check the optical density, 1 mL of culture is taken in a cuvette and absorbance is measured at 600 nm using a spectrophotometer.
After 4 h of protein expression at 37°C, harvest cells by centrifugation at 3000 g for 15 min at 4°C.
Protein Purification Day 1.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 20 mL of TDP1 breaking buffer (100 mM KCl, 30 mM K3PO4 pH 7.0, 1× Protease Inhibitor cocktail) with 20 s vortexing after every 30 min for 4 h on ice.

Sonicate the cells at 30% amplitude for 30 s followed by 2 min pause on ice for a total pulse time of 30 min using a probe sonicator.
Clear the sonicated sample by centrifugation at 15,000 × g for 30 min at 4°C.
Collect the supernatant and then filter it through a 0.22 μm syringe filter.
Load the filtered supernatant onto 5 mL packed Whatman Cellulose Phosphate P11 column.
Wash the P11 column with 10 mL phosphocellulose wash buffer (400 mM KCl, 30 mM K3PO4 pH 7.0, 1× Protease Inhibitor cocktail).
Elute with 10 mL phosphocellulose elution buffer (800 mM KCl, 30 mM K3PO4 pH 7.0, 1× Protease Inhibitor cocktail).
Desalt the eluate using PD-10 column (GE Healthcare) equilibrated with dialysis buffer/ Ni2+-NTA equilibration buffer without KCl (50 mM KH2PO4, 50 mM K2HPO4, 400 mM NaCl, 10 mM Imidazole, 1 mM DTT, 1× Protease Inhibitor cocktail).
Equilibrate the Ni2+-NTA agarose bead (500 μL) silica column with equilibration/binding buffer (50 mM KH2PO4, 50 mM K2HPO4, 400 mM NaCl, 100 mM KCl, 10% Glycerol, 10 mM Imidazole, 1 mM DTT, 1× Protease Inhibitor cocktail) twice.
Load the desalted eluate onto the column and collect the flow through on a coaster.
Wash the column with 8 column volumes (CV). TDP1 Ni2+-NTA wash buffer containing 50 mM KH2PO4, 50 mM K2HPO4, 400 mM NaCl, 100 mM KCl, 10% Glycerol, 30 mM Imidazole and 1 mM DTT.
Pass 6 CV of Ni2+-NTA elution buffer containing 50 mM KH2PO4, 50 mM K2HPO4, 400 mM NaCl, 100 mM KCl, 10% Glycerol, 300 mM Imidazole and 1 mM DTT.
Collect the elute as 1 mL fractions and store at −80°C.

Pool elution fraction and dialyze using a dialysis membrane overnight for 12–18 h at 4°C in 1 L of storage/elution buffer without imidazole containing 50 mM KH2PO4, 50 mM K2HPO4, 400 mM NaCl, 100 mM KCl, 10% Glycerol, and 1 mM DTT.
Note: Prepare this reagent fresh every time and do not store for longer than a day.
Note: TDP1 purity was determined as a single band ∼70 kDa band representing over 95% of the detectable proteins stained by Coomassie after SDS–polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis (SDS-PAGE) as described27[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib27] (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Protein Purification Day 2.
Concentrate the TDP1 protein by loading the dialyzed eluate in a 50 kDa cut concentrator and centrifuge for 20 min at 800 × g.
Pool fractions containing protein of interest, concentrate, and freeze aliquots in liquid nitrogen for storage at −80°C. Measure protein concentration using Bradford assay with BSA standard and run on an SDS-PAGE to check purity.
In vitro methylation of recombinant TDP1 protein
Timing: 1 day
The proposed protocol uses the human PRMT5 fused to a FLAG tag protein (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). Here, PRMT5 is present in its native form along with its co factors and post translational modifications (PTM). The pCMV-Tag2B-FLAG-PRMT5 is transfected in HEK293 cells and immunoprecipitated (IP) using anti-FLAG antibody (anti-mouse antibody M2 F3165) as described for FLAG-TDP1 (next section).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],28[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib28]
Add 8 μL of FLAG-PRMT5 IP beads with 2 μg of recombinant TDP1 protein in methylation buffer containing 50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 8.5), 5 mM MgCl2, 4 mM DTT and 100 μM SAM (S-(5_-adenosyl)-L-methionine chloride dihydrochloride) in a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube.
Incubate the microcentrifuge tube at 30°C for 2 h.
Stop the reaction by adding 2×SDS loading buffer (Invitrogen) and boiling the samples for 5 min.

Note: Check the methylation signal on TDP1 by running the reaction mixture on a SDS PAGE and probing with SDMA antibody (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]A and 5B) before proceeding to fluorescence cleavage assay using in vitro methylated TDP1.
Note: Different types of in vitro modifications assay such as phosphorylation or ubiquitination can also be performed on recombinant TDP1 before proceeding to FRET-based TDP1 cleavage assay to check the effect of different PTM on TDP1 activity in real time.
Purification of immune complexes of TDP1 protein (ex-vivo)
Timing: 3–5 days
The proposed protocol uses the human TDP1 fused to a FLAG-tagged protein (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]). The FLAG fusion facilitates precipitation of ectopically expressed TDP1 with anti-FLAG antibodies (anti-mouse antibody M2 F3165).1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],11[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11],28[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib28] Here, TDP1 is present in its native form along with its co factors and post-translational modifications.
Transfection of mammalian TDP1 construct.
Seed HEK293 cells in two T-25 in order to achieve 70% confluency next day (2∗106 cells).
Next day, transfect HEK293 cells with pCMV-Tag2B-FLAG-TDP1 (FLAG-TDP1) using Lipofectamine 2000 following the manufacturer’s protocol.
Note: We established this protocol with HEK293 cell lines. HEK293 are cultured in DMEM supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% penicillin/streptomycin. However, other cell lines may also be used.
Note: We have found that TDP1 expression is optimal at 48 h following transfection in HEK293 cell line as analyzed by Western blotting against anti-FLAG antibodies (anti-rabbit F7425).
Critical: Avoid the use of antibiotics during transfection. Antibiotics can reduce transfection efficiency or cause cell death.
Co-immunoprecipitation using FLAG antibody.
48 h post transfection, centrifuge cells at 1,500 × g for 6 min at 4°C.
Resuspend and wash the total pellet with ice-cold PBS followed by centrifugation, repeat PBS wash.

Resuspend the pellet in 200 μL of ice-cold 1× IP lysis buffer (50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 8.), 300 mM NaCl, 0.4% NP-40, 5 mM DTT and 1×protease inhibitor cocktail) for 1 h and vortex every 15 min for proper cell lysis. After incubation, centrifuge the cells at 15,000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Collect 10% supernatant (lysate) in a separate microcentrifuge tube for input sample.
Collect the remaining supernatant (lysate) in an IP vial and add 100 μL IP dilution buffer (50 mM Tris–HCl (pH 8.), 0.4% NP-40, 5 mM DTT and 1× protease inhibitor cocktail).
Incubate the diluted lysate with 100 μL Protein A/G beads (50% slurry) at 4°C for 30–60 min for preclearing the cell lysate.
Centrifuge the mixture at 15,000 × g for 1 min at 4°C, collect the supernatant in a new IP vial.
Incubate the diluted lysate with 10 μL (10 μg/mL) anti-FLAG antibody (anti-mouse antibody M2 F3165) in an end-over-end rotator at 4°C for 1 h.
Add 100 μL Protein A/G beads to the FLAG antibody mixed lysate and incubate it in a rotator at 4°C overnight (12–18 h).
Next day, centrifuge the mixture at 15,000 × g for 1 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend the beads in 1 mL IP wash buffer followed by centrifugation at 15,000 × g for 1 min at 4°C. Repeat the IP wash twice.
Discard the supernatant keeping the beads. Store the beads in −80°C degree.
Note: The amount of antibody and Protein A/G agarose beads can vary depending on transfection efficiency and variability of cell lines.
Note: Check the methylation signal on TDP1 by running the IP reaction mixture on a SDS PAGE and probing with SDMA antibody (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B) before proceeding to fluorescence cleavage assay.

Critical: The timing for cell lysis will vary depending on the number of cells and cell line. It may be necessary to incubate longer to ensure complete cell lysis.
Preparation of Top1cc/3′DNA lesions mimetic substrate
Timing: 1 day
This protocol utilizes a double stranded and single stranded fluorescence-quencher DNA probe which mimics Top1cc/3′DNA lesion substrate.13[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib13] Both DNA substrates contains 5′ 5(6)-carboxyfluorescein (56-FAM) and 3′ Black Hole Quencher (3BHQ) (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Preparation of 18 nucleotide ssDNA substrate (HEI-40) (5′-FAM/AGA GGA TCT AAA AGA CTT/3′-BHQ).
Dissolve the synthesized oligo HEI-40 obtained from IDT (HPLC purified) in an oligo dissolving buffer (10 mM Tris pH 8.0 and 50 mM NaCl) to a final concentration of 50 μM.
Preparation of dsDNA substrate (HEI-50) (56-FAM/AAG TCT TTT AGA TCC CTC CGG ATC TAA AAG ACT T/3BHQ).
Dissolve the synthesized oligo HEI-50 obtained from IDT in an oligo dissolving buffer (10 mM Tris pH 8.0 and 50 mM NaCl) to a final concentration of 50 μM.
Heat HEI-50 at 80°C for 10 mins and snap-cool rapidly on ice to promote hairpin formation.
Note: The sequence of the 34 nt HEI-50 is self-complementary, apart from the central 4 nt, and can form a 15 bp double-stranded hairpin structure.
Critical: The hairpin formation of dsDNA (HEI-50) needs to be made just before starting the assay reaction and maintained at 4°C before use.
Critical: The substrates are light-sensitive. It is important to minimize exposure to light.
Execution of fluorescence cleavage assay of TDP1
Timing: 60–90 min

In this step, we mix varying concentrations of TDP1 recombinant protein (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4] and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]) or TDP1 immune complex (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]) with a fixed concentration of fluorescently-quenched labeled oligos (HEI-40 and HEI-50) in the presence of a cleavage assay buffer to start the TDP1 cleavage reaction. The catalytic activity of TDP1 is monitored by increase in BHQ cleavage which is reflected by enhanced fluorescence intensity of the FAM fluorophore with time.
Set up the cleavage assay reaction as shown in the table below.
The working stocks of TDP1 recombinant protein or TDP1 immune complexes and TDP1 substrates (HEI-40/HEI-50) were kept on ice. The cleavage assay buffer was kept on ice.
Make a master mix to minimize error.
Samples can be mixed in a microcentrifuge tube and transferred to a well in 96-well plate or mixed directly in the well.
Note: Add the enzyme (TDP1) at the end just before putting the plate inside the reader. This step must be completed as quickly as possible to capture rapid kinetics of TDP1 activity.
Critical: Use a new tip to load the TDP1 enzyme for each well to avoid cross contamination between wells and load the samples in the wells using a 45oangle to avoid the formation of bubbles.
Add 100 μL of cleavage assay buffer to a well as a blank buffer control.
Add reaction mixture to a well as a negative control.
Measure fluorescence intensity of all samples using the setting described in materials and equipment.
When the measurement is done, save the data and take the plate out of the plate reader.
Critical: In the SpectraMax M5 multimode microplate reader acquisition setting, ensure the Shake and Read steps are indented during the Kinetic steps.

Note: Other Fluorescence microplate reader such as ThermoFisher Scientific Varioskan LUX may also be used to measure the fluorescence signal.
